Comment: They’re fighting to keep corporate interests in power. They know corporate America will probably ditch Trumpism and MAGA, or at least are just about ready to do so. Of course, they need a recession first.   You can see this with RFK JR playing out right now, and he’s likely going to be the test case for how much intellectual “diarrhea” voters will accept. RFK has said he plans to figure out the cause of autism by September. Truth is, he’s not going to do any research, instead he will be going on all these podcasts over the course of months to talk about it with podcasters. This will make MAGA’s feel like it was a very transparent process and they will be in tune with every update made on each podcast. Will probably start off with the bigger podcasters. Anyways, the gist is that there is no cure or remedy for Autism besides stimulants. But stimulants are prescribed in a very narrow range of cases. Expect the classic, “adderall=meth” and all the MAGAs will be outraged that the cure for Autism is hardcore illegal drugs. At that moment, RFK will switch up to talk about “miracle cures” touted by naturalists and have a personal anecdote. Expect the mainstream media like the NYTimes to put a very soft fight and “expose” the personal anecdotes. If voters still aren’t too skeptical, then corporate interests will have won.   By the way, a strange thing is happening. It seems like Conservatives are launching a full scale attack campaign against medical privacy. First we have abortions, then trans medical treatment, and finally autism databases. It all seems to be converging on eroding medical rights.   Anyways, at the end of it all is the Democrat party. Comment: It's not worth it.  Even aside from this, Hogg is a one-trick pony. He's gun control or bust and celebrated Democratic losses just because a Democrat was pro-2A. He doesn't seem to have other significant policy positions.  At this particular moment, I hope it's not lost on anyone that a *lot* of Democrats and independents who may not have been that interested in gun rights are reevaluating their positions at a time when Trump is considering invoking the insurrection act. So the one position Hogg is known for will crater his influence with voters across the entire political spectrum.  The DNC went with Hogg because he's young, but he's not cut out for this. If he wants to run his own agenda, he can do that on his own. There are plenty of other candidates who could execute his role more effectively and become more reliable standard bearers for reinvigorating the party.  My local Democratic party's been a zombie party for the last decade. Hogg came to town for a fundraiser last month and gave an inkling of life to them. Problem is, you had to spend a minimum $500 just to get into the reception and get kicked out a short while later. Dinner was more expensive and went up as high as $20,000. I'm sure they raised some money so my local party can keep sucking in oxygen but he did fuck-all for actually energizing voters while he was in town.

Comment: Oh, Fucking PLEASE! The Democratic Party of the past 30 years spends 50 percent of the time making certain they are positioned to be the only opposition to the Republicans, and the other 50 percent giving the Republicans basically everything they want... do you wonder why their approval rating is 27 percent?!? This is during the age of MAGA and the Congress with people Like MTG and Josh Hawley, and the Roberts SCOTUS, they still have an abysmal approval rating. Continue the definition of insanity because the alternative might be seen as "a circular firing squad"?  Or put it another way, it's likely we've already lost this country to an authoritarian dictator, maybe there's hope that the system can hold until another election, maybe not, but I do know this about the history of the past one hundred twenty five or one hundred fifty years: every government that fell before being taken over by the worst dictators of any stripe... whether the right wing fascists or the left wing communists, they all fell because the government they defeated was either too weak, too corrupt, too out of touch, or a combination of those things. And the party that lost to Donald Trump is in the position it is now because it has been all of those things, and cannot stop being those things without drastic changes. It cannot hope to take back this country with the current old, out of touch, pandering to the billionaires and the same corporate interests as the current "feel your pain" Democratic leadership of the past twenty five to thirty years. It needs the shake up for any hope of survival, if it isn't already too late.

Comment: It wasn’t “tradition” it’s called the advantage of incumbency. It’s a known quantity in poly sci.  Serious candidates don’t run against an incumbent, because even if they win it’s basically a guaranteed loss in the general. When the incumbent doesn’t run again, unless there are extenuating circumstances (e.g. Johnson taking over for Kennedy after the assassination), the incumbent party loses the presidential election.  It’s why no serious candidates would run against Biden. This isn’t a DNC thing. It was on Biden. He should not have run.  You’ll also notice that the GOP did the same thing. Trump didn’t have a primary challenge in 2020 for the same reason.  Bush, Obama, Clinton, Reagan all didn’t have primary challenges. Bush sr had to deal with Perot, and that most likely cost him the election.
Author: mightcommentsometime

Comment: No one’s saying votes were switched. We’re saying the institution responsible for running a neutral primary was actively working behind the scenes to favor one candidate.  Debbie Wasserman Schultz stepping down from the DNC wasn’t for “not being nice.” It was because internal emails confirmed that she and the DNC violated their own charter, which requires neutrality in the primary process.
Author: pappagallo19

Comment: Rigged isn't the right word since they didn't literally steal votes. But the DNC very clearly tilted the playing field in favor of Clinton.   Debbie Wasserman Schultz had to resign as DNC chair due to leaked emails showing the DNC violated their supposed neutrality by discussing ways to undermine Bernie.   Hillary had an agreement with the DNC early on that gave her more control over how campaign money was raised and spent, basically giving her control of the party before she was the nominee.   The DNC scheduled fewer debates than previous election cycles and scheduled them during low-viewership times to limit Sanders' visibility.   So it really depends on your definition of "rigged." If you mean "votes were stolen" then obviously no. If you mean "the DNC acted in ways that unfairly advantaged Clinton and violated its own neutrality" then I'd argue yes.

Comment: Calling it "normal politics" is the crux of the problem. That doesn't justify it. It reveals the rot in the system.   If a supposedly neutral party governing a primary election is allowed to quietly tip the scales and coordinate with one candidate behind the scenes, and we just shrug and say “well, that’s how it goes,” then what’s the point of pretending it’s a democratic process at all?  You can believe Sanders would’ve lost anyway,  and still be honest about the fact that the process wasn’t clean. Superdelegates declared for Clinton before a single vote was cast, creating a media narrative that the race was already over. Yes, she won by a wide margin, but that win was built atop a structural and narrative advantage that the DNC helped shape.   And re: the financial agreement, I would recommend reading Donna Brazile's behind the scenes account where she describes how Clinton's team had control over staffing and strategy months before her nomination. She explicitly states that the DNC was financially dependent on Clinton. Sanders could have signed on after the fact, but Clinton's team was already steering the ship.
